generic: Respiratory Syncytial Virus Immune Globulin, Human
drugs: Respiratory Syncytial Virus Immune Globulin, Human

0.title: Generic Names
0.mono: Respiratory Syncytial Virus Immune Globulin, Human

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono:
• Respiratory syncytial virus immune globulin (Respigam(R)) is no longer available in the United States.
  • Respiratory syncytial virus infection, In children with bronchopulmonary dysplasia or a history of premature birth (35 weeks gestation or less); Prophylaxis: 750 mg/kg IV monthly during RSV season (typically begins November, through April); total of 5 doses

3.title: Indications
3.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Respiratory syncytial virus immune globulin (Respigam(R)) is no longer available in the United States [1].
  • Respiratory syncytial virus infection, In children with bronchopulmonary dysplasia or a history of premature birth (35 weeks gestation or less); Prophylaxis

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• hypersensitivity to Respiratory Syncytial Virus immune globulin or other human immunoglobulin
  • selective IgA deficiency
  • infants and children with hemodynamically significant congenital heart disease

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• pre-existing renal insufficiency
  • underlying pulmonary disease or congestive heart failure; sensitivity to fluid volume
  • clinically apparent fluid overload
  • monitor patients for fluid overload, especially patients with bronchopulmonary dysplasia
  • meales-mumps-rubella and varicella vaccines should be deferred for 9 months after the last dose of RSVIG

2.title: Moderate
2.mono:
• Measles Virus Vaccine, Live (probable)
  • Mumps Virus Vaccine, Live (probable)
  • Rotavirus Vaccine, Live (probable)
  • Rubella Virus Vaccine, Live (probable)
  • Smallpox Vaccine (probable)
  • Varicella Virus Vaccine (probable)

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Rash
  • Gastrointestinal:Diarrhea, Gastroenteritis, Vomiting
  • Other:Fever
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Hypertension (1%), Hypotension (rare), Tachyarrhythmia (1%)
  • Endocrine metabolic:Hypervolemia (1%)
  • Hematologic:Desaturation of blood (1%)
  • Respiratory:Respiratory crackles (1%), Respiratory distress, Exacerbation (2%), Tachypnea (1%), Wheezing (2%)

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Systemic: RSV-IGIV contains a high concentration of neutralizing and protective antibodies directed against RSV . In vitro tests demonstrated that RSV-IGIV can neutralize clinical isolates of RSV .

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Intravenous
  • do NOT dilute
  • initiate infusion at 1.5 mL/kg/hr for 15 minutes; if tolerated increase to 3.6 mL/kg/hr for remainder of infusion
  • especially ill children with bronchopulmonary dysplasia may require a slower infusion rate

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• respiratory status, vital signs
  • renal function, urine output; baseline and periodically following infusion

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Patient should avoid having Measles-Mumps-Rubella and Varicella vaccinations for 9 mo after therapy. Healthcare professional should be consulted before other vaccinations are considered.
  • This drug may cause diarrhea, gastroenteritis, vomiting, and fever.
  • Patients with bronchopulmonary dysplasia have increased risk of fluid overload while taking drug. Advise patient's caretaker to report wheezing, tachypnea, and respiratory distress.
  • Advise patient's caretaker to call healthcare professional if a treatment is missed, as drug must be given on a fixed schedule.
